Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 12:14AM horse-n-around wrote: The drains are the worst for me,  it seems like no matter what I do I can feel tugging on the incisions.  I have lots of slack.  I used a old stocking the tied it around my waist and hooked the safety pins to that instead of my clothes.  Its helped some but, I can still feel it.  I have had less than 2 oz from each drain since coming home (in a 24 hour period) on Friday.  Even in the hosiptal they weren't doing much.  My period also started within 48 hours the surgery, I think that contributed to the migraine nausea issue and to my general feeling cruddy.  Pain hasn't been bad.  I can't wait to get my hair washed either! Yuck! LOL
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2011 05:41AM horse-n-around wrote: Hi Tina I remember the showing feeling really weird to, I actually got a little "light headed" in my first shower, it probably had to do with the weird sensations that the shower was giving me.  but it was great all at the same time to really be able to wash good (mixed emotions).  Sorry you had to have the drains in so long, at least they are out now. Overall I am doing great, the front of my breasts are numb and still really tight, but most of my arm movement is back to normal.  I still stuggle to stretch my arms straight over my head, but I can reach the top shelf of my cuboards finally
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 10:10AM horse-n-around wrote: My head it killing me today, probably stress.  I did some research on the net and it appears Tylenol is OK before surgery (which is in 3 days).  I took some anyways, being Sunday there was no one to call.  I really think its going to turn into a migrane.   Any one remember the don'ts prior to surgery (I was told no advil or asprine products)
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 07:38AM horse-n-around wrote: I just got a call from the PS office,  they are going to pull my last 2 drains at 8:30 am tomorrow I can't wait to actually take a full blown shower!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 01:13AM horse-n-around wrote: Herky, you post about the Twizzlers made me chuckle! I wish I could say I don't remember much of it, but I remember pretty  much all of it.   I had to call my DH at 4am  in the morning (on night #2) to bring me my migraine medicine because the hospital didn't have it in the pharmacy and all I could do was vomit!  The nurses tried all sorts of stuff the night before and nothing was working to get rid of the migraine (even demeral).  He was a tropper and got up, found my medicine and drove it 40+ minutes to the hospital.  About a hour after I took the medicne I was fine, kept food down and got released ny noon!, ctm1,  good to hear from you.   I had my surgery on a weds and it was 5 days before I managed to pass any stool.  I too was taking softeners.  I also was drinkng tons of coffee (thats usually a trigger for me to), The thing was I wasn't having any urges to go either up until I finally did.  Lovely conversation! LOL  oh well.  Glad to hear you node was clear (mine was too luckily)
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 03:23AM horse-n-around wrote: all my nurses were great too.  DH didn't stay either night, nor did he come the day after surgery (I told him he didn't need to, have to save his VAC time and my son had a special event that eve). I really didn't need anyone "extra" there as all I did was want to sleep & puke. On the other hand, I had a OBNOXIOUS woman in the room with me.  The night of my surgery she was on her damn cell phone pratically non-stop from the moment I was wheeled into the room  - it got to be 10pm and I had enough and told her to "quit" I needed to get rest.   She was LOUD and had the worst gravely voice and the more she talked the worse it got.  UGH!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 04:25PM horse-n-around wrote: I went an got a massage today - needed to de-stress a  bit. as far as preparing, not doing to much really.  Family members will take care of the horses.  I plan to pick up some easy fix dinner items (that my 13 yr old daughter can cook).  The recliner has my reserved sign on it (JK).  I have a neck pillow.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 01:43PM horse-n-around wrote: Hi Tina I took some Tylenol and it helped some, still have the headache.  the bright snow outside is killing me when I look out (had to keep a eye on my daughter who was riding her horse in the back yard).   I have prescription med  Relpax and I believe they told me that was OK (that was back in Dec for the original Bioposy surgery).  I just want to make double sure its OK. I am hoping I can  survive on Tylenol till tomorrow  when the offices open up.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 01:08AM horse-n-around wrote: Anyone else get a burning sensation when they get up from laying down.  This AM (and a few other times) I get up and my chest just burns from the skin trying to move/shift.  its like it attaches overnight and when you get it up "pulls aways" and burns.  I don't know how else to discribe it!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 06:45AM horse-n-around wrote: Zenbreats When they took out two of my drains, it stung for a brief moment but really wasn't to bad.  It was actually a relief.  I still have two drains left, not sure why other than the nurse at my PS doesn't seem to think they can come "because it too soon"  even though I have less than 1 oz between both of them in a 24 hour period.  The PS is out of town.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 01:21PM horse-n-around wrote: I went for my first drive this past Sunday, 11 days post BMX.  I have been off pain meds for well over a week.  I needed to go grocery shopping.  Brought by 13 yr old daughter along to drive the cart and handle heavier bags.  I do get tired fast when up running around like that, but driving wasn't a issue.  I just don't like the rough roads.  The jolting of pot holes is a little unconfortable.  The seat belt doesn't bother me.  The only thing that is sore is my underarm where the one node was taken out.  That still hurts to pressue and certain movements
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2011 03:30PM horse-n-around wrote: Hi March ladies, I was in the Feb group.  I found a quick cheap way of keeping the drains more stationary.  I HATED having them attached to clothing articles that moved.  I just used the leg of a panty hose tied aroud my waist.  I hung the drains with the safety pins to that.  The panty hose is very stretchy & soft so is never felt tight, but it held the drains nice & close to my skin. (I had 4 drains).  The visiting nurse service loved it! LOL,  they thought it was quite creative.
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2011 04:19AM horse-n-around wrote: Hi All,  Figured I would check in and see how everyone was doing Life is pretty much back to normal for me, Dr hasn't really released me to do much yet, but have been doing my normal things for a few weeks,  It doesn't bother me to handle the 50# hay bales,saddle my horse, clean stalls or even shovel snow.  I  just do what feels OK,  if it bothers me in the least, I don't continue (raking is one thing that I still can't do comfortably).  I do have a appt with my PS this week,  thats just to check on the healing.  He already told me 4-6 months before we can exchange.  Scars look pretty good.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 08:14AM horse-n-around wrote: Hi Tina thanks,  I have my follow up with the PS tomorrow,  I wonder if I am going to get yelled at! LOL Hopefully things are getting better for you too!

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 05:58PM horse-n-around wrote: welcome pandazankar,  of course you are welcome to join our group (not sure if anyone really wants to though, if you know what I mean I am so not ready for this, surgery is coming soon,  I still need to talk to the PS about the TE and or implants. I hate not knowing if  he can do a straight up exchange or if I have to do the TE process.  The PS did say more than likely I will have to do the TE first, which of course means another surgery later on for the exchange.  I did pick up some supplies getting ready, for D-day.  I am dredding the dye going in the day before, that burned horribly when I was injected for the bioposy.  Enough with the needles already, I feel like a pin cushion.

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 12:14AM horse-n-around wrote: these drains are the worst, had a horrible time sleeping again last night,  no matter what I try they pull, even the slightest movement of the drain drives me crazy,  Two of them are a bit irritated which is probably not helping matters.  I have a visiting nurse service that is supposed to stop by today to check everything out.  In the mean time I am trying to get my appt set up with the PS to get these things out.   ugh, I think I would feel pretty good if it wasn't for those things (yes, I am whining! LOL)
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 12:38PM horse-n-around wrote: Good luck to all of those having surgery this week!   A tip for those without drain holders,  I found using the leg of a panty hose tied around my waist works as a great "belt" to pin the drains to.   I just put a small knot in it to hold it around me, very comfortable because it stretches easily and is not like a firm belt.   Holds the drains close to the tummy and not hanging off your clothes.  The visiting nurses saw my contraption today and loved it. LOL For the seat belt, the best I have come up with is using a small soft fleece blanket between me and the belt.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 08:01AM horse-n-around wrote: Hospital was full, so it was extremey unlikely for me to get a private room,  They told me that when I came in that morning.   One would think the hospitals would have rules about yacking in cell phones and loud visitors after say 9 or 10 pm.  It just amazes me how rude people are sometimes
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 09:14PM horse-n-around wrote: Tina,  I was told the pre-op physical had to be done within 30 days of surgery. That could be why you aren't scheduled for one. It does seem the the 16th is a popular day for surgery.   I am dreading the anesthesa more than losing my breasts.  I get horribly sick from,  I told them that the last time I was under for the biopsy and still threw up for almost 8 hrs straight!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 10:14AM horse-n-around wrote: Hi Ladies,  just thought I would stop by quick like,  I came home from the hospital about noon day (stayed 2 nights)  The second night was horrible, I had a migrane come on and puked ever few hours, even with all the meds they were shoving down me.  I am not real sore, just my head is killing me still.  I have 4 drains (2 in each side) and they don't drain much yet, I am told they are working.   The big thing for me is that I actually came home just a little smaller than I went in at.  The PS left my original inplants in and said we would just swap them out at a later time after the MX heals up.  My sentinal node came back clear so that was great news too.   It will be a week or so before I get the full report. Good luck to the rest of the ladies here!  (no I am going to rest my head some more)
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 04:50AM horse-n-around wrote: Hi TinaT,  I have been floating from couch, loveseat to recliner!  Sometimes all in the same night.  The holder I made up works fine, it keeps everything  pretty stationairy, its just I am not a "back" sleeper so getting confortable has been brutal.   The visiting nurse service just left and said everything looks wonderful.  I have a appt with the PS office this after noon (They were trying to give me a appt for Weds but I pushed to get in today or tomorrow at the latest).  The nurse on the phone was being a PIA and didn't want to believe how low my drainage has been but they she gave me a appt for today.   UGH, it drives me absolutely nuts when they do this. I am hoping they will pull the drains (keeping fingers crossed!)
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 06:55AM horse-n-around wrote: yippee!,  2 of the 4 drains taken out.  One left on each side, more confortable already.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2011 11:45PM horse-n-around wrote: Hi Windlass, I was told no shaving within 3" of any incision (I did anyways, as hairy pits drove me insane).  My node incision was about a inch below my pit area.  Very difficult to wash initially with a sponge bath.  I think I smelled bad for a few days too.  When you finally get to shower its awesome.   I only had one node removed and its still very painful to to the touch &  swollen,  The skin looks good around it.  The PS office told me that many of the nodes are deep in your tissue so its pretty painful when they are removed.  Based on what my one feels like, I couldn't imagine what some of you ladies are going through with having more/all removed! I too was off prescription pain meds within a few days.  I have even gone a couple of days with no advil or tylenol at all.  It definetely gets better.  Getting confortable for sleeping is my biggest hurdle right now.  I spent my first night in a real bed last night with TONS of pillows to prop me up, it was better than the couch, but not by much  :) "Good luck"to all those still waiting for surgery and  a big "heal fast"  to those of us in recovery from surgery.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 09:53AM horse-n-around wrote: Hi Nancy, I am from the Feb group. I know my PS said that how much skin you have left from the MX plays a big role in imediate reconstruction.  He generally won't do it because of that reason.  Most ladies want to stay the same size and  it would put way to much pressure on the stitches and could compromise the skin that is left.  They don't want the skin to die  as that creates more problems Best of luck to all of you!!!
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 03:18PM horse-n-around wrote: I had mine the day before.  only one of the 4 injections was real painful, not sure why only one of them was that brutal.

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 07:51PM horse-n-around wrote: I just turned 45, I had a BMX last weds, no regrets.  Cancer was only on the right (still waiting final pathology from the MX).   I had implants prior to BC, mammograms wren't bad but the bioposy was a nightmare,  that was my main reason for doing the double.  To many "possible" surgerys if something was ever suspicisous on the "good" side.  Not worth it to me, so did em both, no rads this way, no tomax either.
Posts.Title: masectomy in july 2010 and now considering msectomy otherside redninrah horse-n-around
